author: Tanu Kulkarni
text:
It was three people in Talikatte, who began the teaching revolution in the village nearly five decades ago. T.C. Hallalppa, Siddappa, and N. Maliyappa took to the chalk and the blackboard and motivated people to take to teaching ever since.

The late Hallappa’s son, H. Kaleshappa, says that the community traditionally were shepherds (Kurubas).

“As they watched over their flock of sheep, people sang and narrated stories. Although they did not know to read and write, they would grasp things well in the form of song and poems,” he says.

In the 1960s, the three persuaded them to take to education. People from the village realised that pursuing education was the only way to climb the social ladder and encouraged others to become teachers.
title: How the revolution began
